title: He Troubled Himself
subtitle: When Jesus chose to enter our pain

key_verse.text: When Jesus therefore saw her weeping, and the Jews also weeping which came with her, he groaned in the spirit, and was troubled

verses.text: Then when Jesus came, he found that he had lain in the grave four days already.
When Jesus therefore saw her weeping, and the Jews also weeping which came with her, he groaned in the spirit, and was troubled.
Jesus therefore again groaning in himself cometh to the grave. It was a cave, and a stone lay upon it.
And when he thus had spoken, he cried with a loud voice, Lazarus, come forth.
And he that was dead came forth, bound hand and foot with graveclothes: and his face was bound about with a napkin. Jesus saith unto them, Loose him, and let him go.

cards.title: The Question Nobody Asks
cards.subtitle: Why did Jesus weep if He knew the ending?
cards.content:
This is one of the most famous scenes in the Bible: 'Jesus wept' (John 11:35), the shortest verse in Scripture.

But there's something strange here that most people overlook:

‚ùì THE PARADOX:

Jesus KNEW that in less than 10 minutes, Lazarus would be alive. He Himself said earlier: 'This sickness is not unto death, but for the glory of God' (v.4).

So why weep?

ü§î WHAT JESUS COULD HAVE DONE:

Jesus could have simply arrived and said:
‚Ä¢ 'Don't cry, I'm going to resurrect him'
‚Ä¢ 'Watch and see that I am the Messiah'
‚Ä¢ 'In 5 minutes everything will be fine'

But He didn't.

üíî WHAT REALLY HAPPENED:

Instead of jumping straight to the miracle, Jesus:
1. SAW the pain of Mary and the Jews weeping
2. WAS DEEPLY MOVED (twice - v.33 and v.38)
3. WEPT with them
4. ONLY THEN performed the miracle

‚ú® THE REVELATION:

The Holy Spirit showed someone this truth: 'In the natural realm, where Jesus saw people weeping, He could have simply said don't weep, I'm going to raise him, don't worry, and not weep. But He was moved and now I understand much more than I believed.'

Jesus had the POWER to solve the problem, but He CHOSE to FEEL the pain first.

This is the divine humanity of Jesus.
cards.revelation_key: Jesus doesn't just fix your problems with a snap of His fingers. He sits with you in the mud of your anguish BEFORE He executes the miracle.

cards.title: Tarass≈ç: Like Stirring Water
cards.subtitle: The word that changes everything
cards.content:
In John 11:33, your Bible probably says 'was troubled' or 'was deeply moved.' But in the original Greek, the word is much stronger:

üìñ TARASS≈å (Strong G5015: œÑŒ±œÅŒ¨œÉœÉœâ)

Literal meaning:
‚Ä¢ To AGITATE violently
‚Ä¢ To STIR calm water until it becomes turbid
‚Ä¢ To SHAKE like a storm agitating the sea

üåä THE IMAGE:

Imagine a pond of crystal-clear water, in perfect calm. Suddenly, someone puts in a stick and moves it violently. The water becomes agitated, turbid, loses its peace.

THAT is tarass≈ç.

‚ö° THE SHOCKING PART:

The Greek text says: ·ºêœÑŒ¨œÅŒ±ŒæŒµŒΩ ·ºëŒ±œÖœÑœåŒΩ (etaraxen heauton)

Literal translation: 'HE TROUBLED HIMSELF'

‚Ä¢ Etaraxen = ACTIVE verb (He performed the action)
‚Ä¢ Heauton = REFLEXIVE pronoun (to Himself)

üéØ THE CRUCIAL DIFFERENCE:

In us, being troubled is PASSIVE:
‚Ä¢ Circumstances trouble US
‚Ä¢ Pain agitates US
‚Ä¢ News disturbs US

We have no control over it.

But in Jesus, the troubling was ACTIVE:
‚Ä¢ He CHOSE to trouble Himself
‚Ä¢ He DECIDED to agitate His own soul
‚Ä¢ He VOLUNTARILY opened the floodgates of His heart

üí° WHY THIS MATTERS:

Jesus is the Prince of Peace. His soul was in perfect calm. He KNEW Lazarus would live.

But when He saw Mary and the Jews weeping, He DECIDED to let His interior become 'agitated' like a sea in storm.

Why? To ENTER into their pain. Not to remain as a distant observer, but to immerse Himself in human anguish.

greek_words.revelation: Jesus was not 'victim' of an emotion that overcame Him. He CHOSE to agitate His own soul to be near your feeling.
This didn't happen TO Jesus. Jesus MADE it happen to Him. It was a priestly act of voluntary empathy.

cards.revelation_key: Jesus decided to become emotionally vulnerable. The Almighty God chose to 'lose His calm' to be near you in your chaos.

cards.title: Embrimaomai: The Holy Fury
cards.subtitle: Jesus wasn't just sad, He was FURIOUS
cards.content:
There's ANOTHER word in John 11:33 that your Bible probably translates gently. It says Jesus 'groaned in the spirit.'

But in Greek it's much more intense:

üî• EMBRIMAOMAI (Strong G1690: ·ºêŒºŒ≤œÅŒπŒºŒ¨ŒøŒºŒ±Œπ)

Original meaning:
‚Ä¢ The SNORTING of a war horse before battle
‚Ä¢ To GROWL with indignation
‚Ä¢ To feel CONTAINED fury

‚öîÔ∏è THE IMAGE:

Think of a warrior on the battlefield, breathing hard, muscles tense, snorting with rage before launching against the enemy.

THAT is what Jesus felt.

‚ùì BUT AGAINST WHOM?

He wasn't angry with Mary, or Martha, or the Jews.

He was FURIOUS against:
‚Ä¢ DEATH that had destroyed His friends
‚Ä¢ SIN that brought this curse to the world
‚Ä¢ THE ENEMY who came to steal, kill, and destroy

üíî THE CONNECTION WITH TARASS≈å:

Jesus experienced TWO simultaneous emotions:

1Ô∏è‚É£ TARASS≈å (agitation) = Empathy with human pain
2Ô∏è‚É£ EMBRIMAOMAI (fury) = Indignation against death

üéØ WHAT THIS MEANS:

When you're in your darkest moment:
‚Ä¢ Jesus WEEPS with you (empathy)
‚Ä¢ Jesus RAGES for you (justice)

He doesn't look at your pain with clinical indifference. He is MOVED to His core and SNORTS with rage against what is destroying you.

‚ö° THE MIRACLE AFTER THE FURY:

After troubling Himself and becoming furious, Jesus:
‚Ä¢ Walks to the tomb (v.38)
‚Ä¢ Commands them to remove the stone (v.39)
‚Ä¢ SHOUTS with authority: 'LAZARUS, COME FORTH!' (v.43)

It wasn't a polite whisper. It was the ROAR of a Warrior invading death's territory to snatch away a prey.

scripture_connections.text: Now is my soul troubled; and what shall I say? Father, save me from this hour?
When Jesus had thus said, he was troubled in spirit, and testified... One of you shall betray me

cards.revelation_key: Jesus is not a distant God who observes your pain with philosophical calm. He SNORTS with rage against what hurts you and ATTACKS on your behalf.

cards.title: John 14:1 - The Promise After the Pain
cards.subtitle: Why Jesus can tell you 'Let not your heart be troubled'
cards.content:
Here's the most beautiful connection:

After Jesus TROUBLED HIMSELF in John 11, 12, and 13 for us, He has the AUTHORITY to tell us in John 14:

üíé JOHN 14:1:
'Let not your heart be troubled (tarassesth≈ç): ye believe in God, believe also in me.'

Did you notice? It's the SAME WORD: tarass≈ç.

üîë THE DIVINE LOGIC:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Jesus TROUBLED HIMSELF (John 11:33) = He exhausted the troubling for you
2Ô∏è‚É£ Jesus drank the entire cup of pain (Gethsemane, Cross)
3Ô∏è‚É£ Now He can COMMAND you not to be troubled

‚òï THE ANALOGY:

It's as if there were a cup of bitterness that someone has to drink. Jesus says:
'I'm going to drink the ENTIRE cup. Every drop of anguish, every wave of trouble, every moment of agony. And when I'm finished, YOU won't have to drink it.'

‚ú® THAT'S WHY HE CAN SAY:
'Let not your heart be troubled' - because HE already troubled Himself in your place.

üéÅ WHAT THIS GIVES YOU TODAY:

When your soul is agitated like water in a storm:
‚Ä¢ It's not because God doesn't understand (He TROUBLED HIMSELF)
‚Ä¢ It's not because you're alone (He ENTERED your chaos)
‚Ä¢ It's not because there's no way out (He DRANK the entire cup)

üí™ THE AUTHORITY OF HIS COMFORT:

Jesus can comfort you because He has the 'scars' of that same troubling in His own spirit. He doesn't speak to you as a stranger who never suffered. He speaks as Someone who:
‚Ä¢ Chose to trouble Himself
‚Ä¢ Knows what it feels like
‚Ä¢ Overcame the troubling
‚Ä¢ And now offers you His peace

üïäÔ∏è HEBREWS 4:15:
'For we have not an high priest which cannot be touched with the feeling of our infirmities; but was in all points tempted like as we are.'

Jesus didn't 'forget' what it feels like to be agitated. He retained His humanity so that when you speak to Him about your pain, you're not speaking to a stranger.
cards.identity_statement: Your troubling doesn't surprise Jesus, because He chose to trouble Himself BEFORE you. Your agitation doesn't push Him away, because He agitated HIMSELF to be near you.
cards.revelation_key: Jesus can ask you not to let your heart be troubled because He already exhausted all the troubling for you. He drank the cup so you could drink of His peace.

discovery_questions.question: Have you thought that Jesus doesn't understand your pain because He's God and 'always knows how the story ends'? How does it change things to know He CHOSE to agitate His soul to enter your chaos?
When you're in your darkest moment, do you see Jesus as someone who just wants to 'fix the problem quickly,' or as someone who first sits with you in the mud before doing the miracle?

Did you know that Jesus is FURIOUS (embrimaomai) against what's destroying you? How does it change your perspective to know He doesn't look at your pain with indifference, but SNORTS with rage on your behalf?
Jesus says 'Let not your heart be troubled' AFTER troubling Himself for you. Are you willing to give Him your agitation, knowing He already carried it for you?

prayer.title: Prayer of Surrender
prayer.content:
Jesus, today I discover something new about You: that You are not a distant God who observes my pain from afar. You CHOSE to trouble Yourself, DECIDED to agitate Your own soul, became FURIOUS against the death that threatens me.

Thank You that You don't ask me to be at peace from a place of heavenly comfort, but from the place of Someone who DRANK the cup of troubling for me.

Today I give You my agitated water, my soul in storm, my troubled heart. You know what it feels like. You entered here voluntarily.

Just as You shouted to Lazarus 'COME FORTH!', shout over my situation. Snort with rage against what's destroying me. And give me Your peace, that peace only You can give because You already exhausted the troubling for me.

In the name of the One who wept for me, who was moved for me, who roared for me: Jesus. Amen.
